awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Evolution of allosomes and dosage compensation in terrestrial isopods
awd_abstract_narration:
Allosomes are chromosomes that determine sex, like the X and Y chromosomes in mammals, and they play crucial roles in the evolutionary biology of species. They have evolved independently in a wide array of species, and while these chromosomes in different groups share many similarities, they also exhibit important differences. Explaining these differences, however, remains difficult. While a strong body of theoretical work makes several important predictions regarding the evolution of allosomes, conclusively testing those predictions has been difficult because most prior research has focused on a small subset of model organisms. This project will address this problem by examining allosomes in terrestrial isopod crustaceans, which include woodlice and pillbugs. Terrestrial isopods are an ideal group for these questions because they exhibit considerable variation in sex-determining mechanisms, but, surprisingly, their genomes have received little attention. The proposed experiments are designed to help explain why these chromosomes are so unique, and how they contribute to vital biological processes. Importantly, this project will also promote diversity in science and create hands-on educational opportunities for students, especially engaging those from under-served groups. First, a project-based genomics course will be developed, and course materials made publicly available. Second, an international summer program will be established that provides undergraduates at SUNY Oswego with opportunities to conduct research abroad. Finally, this work will generate interest in research on campus by allowing incoming freshmen participating in an existing science and math summer 'bridge' camp to take part in interdisciplinary laboratory activities.

This project will address key questions on the evolution of allosomes in three species of terrestrial isopod crustaceans (Trachelipus rathkei, Porcellio laevis, and Armadillidium vulgare).  This research will (i) identify where changes in sex-determining chromosomes have occurred on the isopod evolutionary tree; (ii) test whether genes on these chromosomes are affected more strongly than autosomal genes by natural selection and genetic drift; and (iii) test whether these species exhibit dosage compensation.  A comparative approach using whole genome sequencing and gene annotation via RNA sequencing will be used to address the first two aims. Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) will also be used to determine homology of allosomes among species. The sex of terrestrial isopods can be experimentally manipulated through surgical ablation or implantation of androgenic glands, which offers a unique opportunity to accurately test for dosage compensation using RNA sequencing in manipulated and unmanipulated individuals of the same and opposite sex.  By studying a unique taxonomic group, this research will help examine the generality of patterns suggested by earlier work on allosomes, providing significant insights into these influential components of so many organisms' genomes, including those of humans.

por.por_cntn:
Allosomes are chromosomes that determine whether a developing embryo becomes male or female. For example, in mammals, embryos carrying one X chromosome and one Y chromosome typically become males, while embryos carrying two X chromosomes typically develop into females; in other groups like birds, on the other hand, two copies of a Z chromosome usually result in male development whereas one Z and one W chromosome triggers female development. Allosomes have evolved independently numerous times in a wide variety of plant and animal species, and they have important consequences on other aspects of an organism's biology. For instance, the fact that some individuals in a species may carry two X chromosomes while other have just one X chromosome, sets up imbalances in gene dosage, which in some species are equalized by genetic pathways known as dosage compensation. Biologists are still trying to understand why allosomes are evolutionarily stable in some groups of organisms but change rapidly in others, as well as why and how allosomes have different consequences, such as dosage compensation, in different species. Studying allosomes in a wider variety of species is especially important for answering these types of questions because most past research has focused on just a handful of well studied laboratory model organisms.

Terrestrial isopods, informally known as woodlice and pillbugs, are a unique group of crustaceans with especially interesting allosomes due to their evolutionary interactions with a bacterium called Wolbachia. Wolbachia is an endosymbiont, a bacterial "parasite" that lives inside the cells of a host isopod, and is passed on from mother to offspring via eggs, but is not transmitted sperm. As a result, Wolbachia has evolved the ability to manipulate its host's reproduction to its own advantage; namely, in many isopod species, Wolbachia can cause hosts carrying male genotypes (e.g., XY chromosomes) to develop as reproductive females. As a result, isopod allosomes are thought to evolve rapidly. This project set out to test this hypothesis, and to examine the evolutionary consequences of changes in allosomes, by looking at allosomes across multiple isopod species and comparing patterns of gene expression and molecular evolution.

This work supported the idea that allosomes have changed frequently across the isopod evolutionary tree. For instance, in one focal species, Trachelipus rathkei, a recent evolutionary switch from a ZZ/ZW allosome system (similar to birds) to an XX/XY system (similar to mammals) was uncovered, and a recent duplicate of a male hormone gene was found on the Y chromosome. Different isopod species seem to have different allosomes, and no evidence of dosage compensation was found in T. rathkei, probably because its evolutionarily young X and Y chromosomes still share most of the same genes, and therefore there are few gene dosage imbalances to "correct" in the first place.

This research was conducted largely by undergraduate students, and provided hands-on training opportunities in the rapidly growing fields of genomics and bioinformatics. Fourteen students contributed to this project through independent study during summers or for credit during the academic year, and another 39 students developed related projects in a capstone genomics course using data generated by this project. More than 100 first-year students learned about finding research opportunities from student researchers at a summer "bridge" program for incoming STEM majors, and several dozen local elementary school students learned about isopods and their ecology through presentations by student researchers via the "Exploring Nature" program at a local biological field station. New resources, including genome and transcriptome sequence data from terrestrial isopods, were made publicly available to the genomics research community, a valuable contribution given that relatively few genomics studies have been done in crustaceans. Fourteen poster or oral presentations were given at regional or national conferences, and six peer-reviewed articles have been published involving the results of this work, including papers on both the main research aims as well as collaborative and student-led projects on related topics such as mitochondrial genome evolution and the evolution of bacterial parasites and endosymbionts.
